An algebra $B$ over a ring $A$ is defined as a ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$. A homomorphism between two $A$-algebras $B$ and $C$ is a ring homomorphism $B \longrightarrow C$ that is compatible with the defining homomorphisms $A \longrightarrow B$ and $A \longrightarrow C$, ensuring the commutativity of the diagram involving these maps.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Does the concept of a/an Algebra over a Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Finitely generated module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a finitely generated module involves a module over a ring having a finite set of generators. This definition requires the understanding of modules and rings, but does not inherently require the concept of an algebra over a ring. An algebra over a ring involves a more specific structure where there is a ring homomorphism from a ring A to another ring B, making B an A-algebra. This concept is more specialized and pertains to the relationship between two rings rather than the internal structure of a module over a single ring. Therefore, understanding or defining a finitely generated module does not depend on the concept of an algebra over a ring, as the latter deals with additional structures and relationships not necessary for the former.
